name: Khachapuri
blurb: A warm, boat-shaped bread filled with melted cheese and topped with a runny egg.

ingredients: 2 large eggs (1 for dough, 1 for topping)
2 cups shredded cheese (mozzarella, feta, or sulguni)
instructions: In a large bowl, combine flour and yeast. Stir in warm milk and 1 egg to form a soft dough.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes, then cover and let rise in a warm place for 1 hour until doubled in size.
Preheat oven to 220°C (425°F). Divide dough in half and shape each into a boat shape on a parchment-lined baking sheet.
Fill the center of each boat with shredded cheese, leaving a border.
Bake for 15 minutes until golden. Remove, make a well in the cheese, and crack an egg into each. Return to oven for 3-4 minutes until egg white is just set.
Top with a pat of butter and serve hot.

name: Injera with Stew
blurb: A spongy flatbread used to scoop up richly spiced lentils and stew.

instructions: In a bowl, mix teff flour and water. Cover and let ferment at room temperature for 2 days.
Stir in salt. Heat a nonstick pan over medium heat and pour a thin layer of batter. Cook until holes form and surface is set. Remove and repeat for all batter.
Rinse lentils and cook in boiling water until tender, about 20 minutes. Drain.
In a pan, sauté onion in oil until soft. Add berbere spice and cooked lentils, stir to combine and heat through.
Serve lentil stew over injera flatbreads.

name: Okonomiyaki
blurb: A savory pancake layered with cabbage and toppings, grilled to crispy perfection.

instructions: In a bowl, mix flour, eggs, and 1/2 cup water until smooth. Fold in shredded cabbage.
Heat a nonstick skillet over medium heat and pour in half the batter, shaping into a round pancake.
Top with half the pork belly slices. Cook for 4-5 minutes, then flip and cook another 4 minutes until golden and pork is cooked.
Repeat for second pancake. Drizzle with okonomiyaki sauce and mayonnaise before serving.

name: Feijoada
blurb: A hearty stew of black beans simmered with various cuts of meat and aromatic spices.

instructions: Rinse and soak black beans overnight in plenty of water.
Drain beans. In a large pot, brown pork and beef with onion and garlic over medium heat.
Add soaked beans, bay leaves, and enough water to cover. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 2 hours, stirring occasionally.
Season with salt and pepper. Serve hot with rice and orange slices if desired.

name: Mansaf
blurb: A rich, comforting rice and lamb dish with a tangy fermented yogurt sauce.

ingredients: 200g jameed (dried yogurt), soaked and blended with 4 cups water
instructions: Soak jameed in water overnight, then blend until smooth.
In a large pot, cook lamb in jameed liquid over medium heat until tender (about 1.5 hours).
Meanwhile, cook rice according to package instructions.
Toast almonds in a dry pan until golden.
To serve, spread rice on a platter, top with lamb and sauce, and garnish with almonds and parsley.

name: Gado-Gado
blurb: A colorful platter of cooked vegetables, tofu, and eggs served with a rich peanut dressing.

instructions: Boil potatoes and green beans in salted water until just tender, then drain.
Fry tofu cubes in a little oil until golden on all sides.
Arrange potatoes, green beans, tofu, and sliced eggs on a serving plate.
Drizzle generously with peanut sauce and serve.

name: Shakshuka
blurb: Poached eggs nestle in a simmering sauce of tomatoes, peppers, and spices.

instructions: Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Sauté onion and bell pepper until soft, about 5 minutes.
Add chopped tomatoes, paprika, and cumin. Simmer for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until sauce thickens.
Make 4 wells in the sauce and crack an egg into each. Cover and cook for 5-7 minutes until eggs are just set.
Serve hot with crusty bread.

name: Schnitzel
blurb: A thin cutlet breaded and fried until golden, served with a squeeze of lemon.

instructions: Pound veal cutlets to 1/4-inch thickness and season with salt and pepper.
Dredge each cutlet in flour, dip in beaten eggs, then coat in breadcrumbs.
Heat oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Fry cutlets 2-3 minutes per side until golden and crisp.
Drain on paper towels and serve with lemon wedges.

name: Kimchi Jjigae
blurb: A fiery stew of aged kimchi, pork slices, and soft tofu in a bold broth.

instructions: In a pot, sauté kimchi and pork belly over medium heat for 3-4 minutes.
Add onion and gochujang, stir well.
Pour in water and bring to a boil. Add tofu, reduce heat, and simmer for 20 minutes.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Ceviche
blurb: Fresh fish marinated in citrus and mixed with herbs and a touch of heat.

ingredients: 300g white fish fillet, cut into 1/2-inch cubes
instructions: Place fish cubes in a bowl and cover with lime juice. Let marinate in the fridge for 30 minutes until opaque.
Drain most of the lime juice. Add onion, chili, and cilantro. Toss gently to combine.
Chill for another 10 minutes before serving.

name: Pierogi
blurb: Soft dumplings filled with mashed potatoes and cheese, served boiled or fried.

instructions: Mix flour and water to form a soft dough. Knead for 5 minutes, cover, and let rest.
Boil potatoes until tender, then mash with cheese. Season with salt and pepper.
Roll out dough and cut into circles. Place a spoonful of filling in each, fold and seal edges.
Boil pierogi in salted water until they float, about 3-4 minutes. Optionally, fry in butter with onions before serving.

name: Biryani
blurb: A fragrant rice dish layered with marinated meat, herbs, and deep spices.

ingredients: 1/4 tsp saffron threads, soaked in 2 tbsp warm milk
instructions: In a bowl, marinate chicken with yogurt and biryani spice mix for at least 1 hour.
Rinse rice and parboil in salted water with whole spices (like cardamom, cloves, bay leaf) for 6 minutes. Drain.
In a large pot, layer half the rice, then chicken, saffron milk, and fried onions. Top with remaining rice.
Cover and steam on low heat for 25 minutes. Fluff and serve hot.

name: Masgouf
blurb: A delicious preparation of freshwater fish that is butterflied and slow-grilled over an open fire, creating a tender and smoky flavor.

ingredients: 1 whole carp or other freshwater fish (about 2-3 lbs)
instructions: Clean and butterfly the fish, keeping it attached at the backbone.
Rub the fish with salt, turmeric, and olive oil.
Prepare a wood or charcoal fire and position the fish on a specialized fish grill rack.
Cook slowly for about 1-2 hours, basting occasionally with a mixture of tamarind and water.
Serve hot with sliced lemons, tomatoes, and fresh herbs.

name: Butter Chicken
blurb: A rich and creamy curry made with tender chicken in a mildly spiced tomato sauce, enriched with butter and cream.

ingredients: 1.5 lbs boneless chicken thighs, cut into pieces
1 tsp each of cumin, coriander, and chili powder
instructions: Marinate chicken in yogurt, lemon juice, and 1 tsp garam masala for at least 30 minutes.
In a large pan, melt butter and sauté garlic and ginger until fragrant.
Add the remaining spices and cook for a minute until aromatic.
Add tomato puree and simmer for 10 minutes until slightly reduced.
Add the marinated chicken and cook until done, about 15 minutes.
Stir in heavy cream and remaining garam masala, simmer for 5 more minutes.
Garnish with fresh cilantro and serve with rice or naan.

name: Kimchi
blurb: A flavorful fermented vegetable dish, typically made with cabbage and radish, seasoned with a spicy and savory paste that develops complex flavors over time.

instructions: Cut cabbage into quarters, remove core, and salt between leaves. Let sit for 2 hours.
Rinse cabbage 3 times and drain for 30 minutes.
Mix garlic, ginger, chili powder, fish sauce, sugar, and water to create a paste.
Add radish and green onions to the paste and mix well.
Coat each cabbage leaf with the mixture, ensuring even distribution.
Pack tightly into a clean jar, leaving 1-inch headspace.
Ferment at room temperature for 1-5 days, then refrigerate. Best after 2 weeks.

name: Tamiya
blurb: Crispy fritters made from ground fava beans mixed with fresh herbs and aromatic spices, deep-fried to perfection.

ingredients: 2 cups dried peeled fava beans, soaked overnight
instructions: Drain soaked fava beans and pat dry.
In a food processor, combine beans, onion, garlic, and herbs. Pulse until finely minced but not pureed.
Transfer to a bowl and mix in spices, baking soda, salt, and pepper.
Let mixture rest for 30 minutes.
Form into small patties, optionally coat with sesame seeds.
Heat oil to 350°F (175°C) and fry patties until golden brown, about 3-4 minutes.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot in pita bread with tahini sauce and vegetables.

name: Okro Soup
blurb: A hearty and mucilaginous soup featuring sliced okra, meat, fish, and aromatic spices, often enjoyed with a starchy side dish.

ingredients: 1 lb assorted meat (beef, goat, or tripe), cut into chunks
1/2 lb smoked fish or dried fish
1 cup spinach or bitter leaf, chopped
instructions: Cook meat with stock cubes, salt, and onion until tender, about 30-40 minutes.
Add smoked fish for the last 10 minutes of cooking.
In a separate pot, heat palm oil and briefly sauté remaining onions.
Add sliced okra and stir-fry for 5 minutes.
Pour in the meat stock with cooked meat and fish.
Add chopped peppers and simmer for 15 minutes.
Add leafy greens in the last 5 minutes of cooking.
Serve hot with fufu, pounded yam, or garri.

name: Ema Datshi
blurb: A simple yet flavorful stew made primarily of hot chilies and cheese, creating a spicy, rich and comforting dish.

ingredients: 2 cups green or red chilies, sliced lengthwise
1/2 cup farmer cheese or feta cheese
instructions: Heat butter in a pot and sauté onions and garlic until translucent.
Add sliced chilies and tomato if using, cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add water and bring to a simmer.
Reduce heat to low and add cheese, stirring gently until melted.
Season with salt and simmer for another 5 minutes until slightly thickened.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Cepelinai
blurb: Large oval-shaped potato dumplings filled with ground meat and served with sour cream and bacon sauce.

instructions: Peel and grate raw potatoes, squeeze out excess liquid using cheesecloth.
Boil, cool, and mash the remaining potatoes.
Mix raw potato pulp with mashed potatoes, add salt.
For filling, sauté onions, mix with ground meat, egg, salt, and pepper.
Form potato mixture into oval shapes, add meat filling, and seal completely.
Boil in salted water for 25-30 minutes until they float and are cooked through.
For sauce, fry bacon until crisp, add sour cream, and heat through.
Serve dumplings topped with bacon and sour cream sauce.

name: Maraq
blurb: A nourishing meat soup with vegetables and aromatic spices, typically served with flatbread for dipping.

ingredients: 1 lb lamb or goat meat, cut into cubes
instructions: Heat oil in a large pot and brown meat on all sides.
Add onions and garlic, sauté until fragrant.
Stir in spices and cook for another minute.
Add tomatoes and cook until softened.
Pour in water or stock, bring to a boil, then reduce heat.
Simmer covered for 45 minutes until meat begins to tenderize.
Add potatoes and carrots, continue cooking for 20-25 minutes until vegetables are tender.
Garnish with cilantro and serve hot with flatbread.

name: Meat Pie
blurb: A handheld savory pie filled with minced meat and gravy encased in golden flaky pastry.

instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
In a pan, sauté onions and garlic until soft. Add beef and brown thoroughly.
Sprinkle flour over meat, stir for 1 minute, then add stock, tomato paste, Worcestershire sauce, and crumbled stock cube.
Simmer for 15 minutes until thickened. Allow to cool.
Cut pastry sheets - larger circles for bottom, smaller for top.
Place larger circles in greased muffin tins, fill with meat mixture.
Cover with smaller pastry circles, sealing edges. Cut a small vent on top.
Brush with beaten egg and bake for 20-25 minutes until golden.
Serve hot with tomato sauce.

name: Arepas
blurb: Round, flat patties made from corn flour, grilled or fried until crispy outside and fluffy inside, often split and filled with various ingredients.

ingredients: Optional fillings: shredded cheese, shredded chicken, black beans, avocado, etc.
instructions: In a large bowl, combine corn meal and salt.
Gradually add warm water, mixing with your hands until no dry spots remain.
Let dough rest for 5 minutes, then knead briefly until smooth.
Divide dough into 8 equal portions and form into balls.
Flatten each ball into a disc about 1/2 inch thick.
Heat oil in a skillet over medium heat.
Cook arepas for 5-7 minutes on each side until golden brown and crisp.
If desired, finish in a 350°F (175°C) oven for 15 minutes to ensure they're cooked through.
Split horizontally and fill with desired ingredients.

name: Dal Bhat
blurb: A hearty combination of lentil soup and steamed rice, often served with various vegetable curries and pickles.

ingredients: 1 cup yellow or red lentils, rinsed
instructions: For rice: Rinse rice until water runs clear. Cook with 4 cups water until fluffy.
For dal: Cook lentils in 3 cups water until soft, about 20-25 minutes.
In a separate pan, heat ghee and add cumin seeds until they splutter.
Add onions, sauté until golden brown. Add garlic and ginger, cook until fragrant.
Add tomatoes and spices, cook until tomatoes break down.
Pour this tempering into cooked lentils, simmer for 5 minutes.
Garnish dal with cilantro.
Serve hot dal alongside rice with optional vegetable sides and pickles.

name: Pad Thai
blurb: Stir-fried rice noodles with a perfect balance of sweet, sour, and savory flavors, typically combined with eggs, tofu, bean sprouts, and crushed peanuts.

ingredients: 2 tbsp palm sugar or brown sugar
Lime wedges and chili flakes for serving
instructions: Soak rice noodles in warm water for 30 minutes until soft but still firm. Drain.
Mix tamarind paste, fish sauce, and sugar in a small bowl.
Heat oil in a wok over high heat. Add garlic and shallots, stir-fry until fragrant.
Add protein and cook until almost done.
Push ingredients to one side, pour eggs into empty space. Scramble until nearly set.
Add drained noodles and sauce mixture. Stir-fry until noodles absorb the sauce.
Add bean sprouts and half the green onions, toss briefly.
Serve hot, garnished with remaining green onions, crushed peanuts, lime wedges, and chili flakes.

name: Momo
blurb: Delicate steamed dumplings filled with spiced meat or vegetables, served with a spicy dipping sauce.

ingredients: 1 lb ground chicken, pork, or vegetables
instructions: Mix flour and water to form a smooth dough. Cover and rest for 30 minutes.
For filling, combine meat, onions, garlic, ginger, green onions, cilantro, cumin, salt, pepper, and oil.
Roll dough into a log and cut into 16 equal pieces.
Roll each piece into a thin circle approximately 3-4 inches in diameter.
Place a tablespoon of filling in the center of each circle.
Fold and pleat edges to form dumplings.
Steam in a steamer lined with cabbage leaves for 15-18 minutes until cooked through.
Serve hot with a spicy tomato-based or sesame dipping sauce.

name: Tam Mak Hoong
blurb: A vibrant, spicy salad featuring shredded unripe papaya, with a perfect balance of sour, sweet, salty, and spicy flavors.

ingredients: 2-6 Thai bird's eye chilies (adjust to taste)
1 tbsp palm sugar or brown sugar
instructions: In a large mortar, pound garlic and chilies until crushed.
Add green beans and pound lightly to bruise them.
Add dried shrimp (if using) and pound briefly.
Add tomato wedges and lightly crush to release juices.
Mix in fish sauce, lime juice, and sugar until combined.
Add shredded papaya and gently pound while mixing to infuse flavors.
Taste and adjust seasonings as needed.
Transfer to a serving dish and sprinkle with crushed peanuts.

name: Fufu
blurb: A starchy, dough-like side dish made by boiling and pounding starchy vegetables into a smooth, elastic consistency.

ingredients: 2 cups cassava flour or 2 large yams
instructions: For easy version: Gradually add cassava flour to boiling water, stirring constantly to prevent lumps.
Continue stirring until mixture becomes thick and smooth.
For traditional version: Peel and cut yams (and plantain if using) into chunks.
Boil until very soft, about 25-30 minutes.
Drain well and transfer to a wooden mortar.
Pound with a pestle, folding mixture regularly until smooth and elastic.
Shape into round balls and serve immediately with soup or stew.
To eat, pinch off a small piece, make an indentation, and use it to scoop up sauce.

name: Solomillo al Whisky
blurb: Tender pork medallions cooked in a rich and flavorful whisky-based sauce with garlic.

ingredients: 1 lb pork tenderloin, cut into medallions
instructions: Season pork medallions with salt and pepper. Lightly dust with flour.
Heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat.
Sear pork for 2-3 minutes per side until golden but still slightly pink inside. Remove and set aside.
Lower heat, add sliced garlic to the same pan, and sauté until fragrant but not browned.
Add whisky to deglaze the pan, scraping up browned bits from the bottom.
Stir in paprika and chicken stock, simmer for 2-3 minutes until slightly reduced.
Return pork to the pan, cook for another 2 minutes until sauce thickens and pork is cooked through.
Garnish with parsley and serve with crusty bread to soak up the sauce.

name: Laksa
blurb: A spicy noodle soup with a rich and aromatic coconut curry broth, topped with seafood, chicken, or tofu.

ingredients: 2 tbsp laksa paste (or red curry paste)
instructions: Soak rice noodles in warm water until soft, then drain and set aside.
In a large pot, simmer laksa paste in a little oil until fragrant.
Add lemongrass and kaffir lime leaves, stir for 30 seconds.
Pour in coconut milk and chicken stock, bring to a gentle simmer.
Add protein and cook until done (about 3-5 minutes for shrimp, 8-10 for chicken).
Season with fish sauce and palm sugar, adjust to taste.
Place noodles in serving bowls, ladle hot soup and protein over them.
Top with bean sprouts, fresh herbs, and serve with lime wedges.

name: Callaloo
blurb: A velvety green soup made from leafy vegetables, okra, and often coconut milk, sometimes including crab or other seafood for added flavor.

ingredients: 2 bunches callaloo leaves or spinach, chopped
1/2 lb crab legs or 1 cup crab meat (optional)
instructions: In a large pot, sauté onions and garlic until translucent.
Add callaloo leaves, okra, pumpkin, scotch bonnet, and thyme.
Pour in water or stock and bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer.
If using crab, add it now. Cover and cook for 20 minutes.
Add coconut milk and simmer for another 10 minutes.
Remove scotch bonnet pepper.
Using an immersion blender, blend until smooth (or leave chunky if preferred).
Season with salt and pepper, serve hot with rice or bread.

name: Ikan Bakar
blurb: Aromatic grilled fish marinated in a spice paste and typically wrapped in banana leaves while cooking to enhance flavor.

ingredients: 2 whole fish (such as snapper or mackerel), cleaned
1 stalk lemongrass, white part only, minced
1 tbsp tamarind paste mixed with 2 tbsp water
instructions: Score fish on both sides with diagonal cuts to help marinade penetrate.
Blend or pound shallots, garlic, chilies, ginger, lemongrass, and turmeric into a smooth paste.
Mix in tamarind liquid, oil, and salt.
Rub marinade all over fish, including inside cavity and cuts. Let marinate for at least 30 minutes.
If using banana leaves, briefly pass them over a flame to soften, then wrap fish.
Grill fish over medium charcoal heat for 6-8 minutes per side until cooked through.
Alternatively, bake at 375°F (190°C) for 20-25 minutes.
Serve hot with lime wedges and rice.

name: Qurutob
blurb: A layered dish featuring torn flatbread soaked in a tangy, reconstituted dried cheese sauce, topped with fried onions and fresh herbs.

ingredients: 2 large flatbreads (such as fatir or mountain bread)
1 cup qurut (dried yogurt balls) or 2 cups greek yogurt with lemon juice
1/2 cup fresh herbs (cilantro, dill, mint) chopped
1 tsp salt (adjust if using greek yogurt substitute)
instructions: If using qurut, soak in warm water for 2-3 hours until soft, then mash into a sauce.
If using yogurt substitute, mix greek yogurt with lemon juice to taste.
Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until golden brown and caramelized.
Tear flatbread into bite-sized pieces.
In a large serving dish, arrange a layer of bread pieces.
Pour the qurut sauce over the bread, allowing it to soak in.
Top with caramelized onions (including the oil).
Sprinkle generously with fresh herbs.
Traditionally served communally from one large plate.

name: Colcannon
blurb: A creamy mashed potato dish mixed with sautéed greens and scallions, finished with a pool of melted butter in the center.

ingredients: 2 lbs potatoes, peeled and cut into chunks
instructions: Place potatoes in a pot, cover with cold water, add salt, and bring to a boil.
Simmer until potatoes are tender, about 15-20 minutes, then drain well.
Meanwhile, blanch kale or cabbage in boiling water for 3-5 minutes, then drain thoroughly.
Mash potatoes thoroughly, add warm milk and half the butter, beat until smooth.
Fold in the blanched greens and chopped green onions.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Transfer to a serving dish, make a well in the center.
Melt remaining butter and pour into the well. Garnish with parsley.

name: Koshari
blurb: A hearty street food dish combining rice, lentils, pasta, and chickpeas, topped with spiced tomato sauce and crispy fried onions.

ingredients: 1 can (15 oz) chickpeas, drained and rinsed
2 tbsp vegetable oil, plus more for frying onions
instructions: Cook lentils in 3 cups water until tender but not mushy, about 20-25 minutes.
In another pot, cook rice according to package directions.
Cook pasta until al dente, drain and rinse with cold water.
For the sauce: Sauté 2 cloves garlic in 2 tbsp oil until fragrant, add tomato sauce, vinegar, half the spices, salt, and pepper. Simmer for 10 minutes.
For crispy onions: Coat sliced onions in flour, fry in hot oil until golden and crisp. Drain on paper towels.
In a small pan, sauté remaining garlic and spices in oil for 1 minute to make a dakka sauce.
To serve: Layer rice, lentils, pasta, and chickpeas. Top with tomato sauce, dakka sauce, and crispy onions.

name: Pizza
blurb: A round flatbread topped with tomato sauce and cheese, baked at a high temperature until the crust is crisp and the cheese melted and bubbly.

ingredients: 1 tbsp olive oil, plus more for drizzling
instructions: For dough: Mix flour, yeast, and salt. Add water and oil, mix until dough forms.
Knead dough for 10 minutes until smooth and elastic. Place in oiled bowl, cover, and let rise for 1-2 hours.
For sauce: Mix crushed tomatoes with garlic, oregano, salt, and pepper.
Preheat oven to highest setting (ideally 500°F/260°C) with pizza stone if available.
Divide dough into 2-3 balls. Stretch or roll each into a thin circle.
Spread sauce thinly over dough, leaving a border for crust.
Top with mozzarella slices.
Bake for 8-10 minutes until crust is golden and cheese is bubbly.
Remove from oven, top with fresh basil and a drizzle of olive oil.

name: Falafel
blurb: Crispy golden orbs made from a blend of legumes and herbs, often enjoyed tucked into warm flatbreads with fresh vegetables.

instructions: Drain soaked chickpeas and blend with onion, garlic, parsley, cumin, flour, salt, and pepper until coarse paste forms.
Chill the mixture for 30 minutes.
Form into small balls or patties.
Heat oil to 350°F (175°C) and fry in batches until deep golden brown.
Drain on paper towels and serve warm.

name: Sushi
blurb: Small, artfully crafted rolls combining seasoned rice with delicate slices of fish or vegetables, often dipped in a salty-savory condiment.

ingredients: 4 oz raw fish (salmon, tuna), thinly sliced
Wasabi and soy sauce for serving
instructions: Cook sushi rice and season with vinegar, sugar, and salt mixture.
Place nori on bamboo mat, spread rice thinly over it.
Add fillings along one edge, roll tightly using the mat.
Slice into bite-sized pieces with a sharp knife.
Serve with wasabi and soy sauce.

name: Croissant
blurb: Flaky, golden layers of laminated dough form a light, buttery crescent-shaped pastry that's both airy and rich.

instructions: Mix flour, sugar, salt, yeast, and milk to form a dough. Rest 1 hour.
Roll out dough, place sliced cold butter in center, fold and roll.
Refrigerate and repeat folds 3 times to laminate.
Roll and cut triangles, shape into crescents.
Let rise until puffy. Bake at 375°F (190°C) until golden.
Cool slightly before serving.

name: Tacos
blurb: A handheld delight built on a soft or crispy shell and layered with savory fillings, fresh toppings, and a squeeze of citrus.

ingredients: 1 lb beef or pork, cooked and shredded
Chili sauce or powder to taste
instructions: Warm tortillas until pliable.
Fill with meat, sprinkle with onion and cilantro.
Drizzle with chili sauce and serve with lime wedges.
Optional: Add avocado or cheese.

name: Chakalaka
blurb: A vibrant vegetable medley simmered with spices, often served as a flavorful companion to grilled dishes or starches.

instructions: Sauté onion and garlic in oil until soft.
Add tomatoes, cook until softened.
Stir in carrots and curry powder, cook 5 mins.
Add beans, mix well, simmer for 10 minutes.
Serve warm or chilled.

name: Chicken Adobo
blurb: A comforting dish featuring tender meat simmered slowly in a tangy, garlicky marinade that reduces into a rich glaze.

instructions: Marinate chicken with soy sauce, vinegar, garlic, bay leaves, and pepper for 30 minutes.
In a pot, brown chicken in oil.
Add marinade and simmer covered for 30–40 minutes.
Uncover and cook until sauce thickens.
Serve hot with rice.

name: Khinkali
blurb: Hand-shaped dumplings with a juicy filling inside, traditionally eaten by hand and known for their signature twist at the top.

instructions: Mix flour, salt, and water into a dough. Let rest 30 mins.
Combine beef, onion, spices, and cold water for filling.
Roll dough thin, cut into circles, place filling in center.
Pleat and twist to seal dumplings.
Boil in salted water until they float + 3 mins more.
Serve hot, traditionally eaten by hand.

name: Poutine
blurb: A hearty dish built around golden fries smothered in warm, savory sauce and soft, slightly squeaky dairy morsels.

instructions: Melt butter in a saucepan, add flour and cook for 2 minutes.
Gradually whisk in broth, stir until thickened.
Season with salt and pepper.
Place hot fries on a plate, top with cheese curds.
Pour hot gravy over the top and serve immediately.

name: Empanadas
blurb: Golden pastry pockets filled with a flavorful mix of seasoned meat and vegetables, often baked or fried for a crispy shell.

instructions: Make dough with flour, oil, and water. Rest 30 minutes.
Cook beef with onion, paprika, salt, and pepper.
Cool, mix in chopped egg.
Roll dough, cut into circles, fill, and fold.
Seal edges, bake at 400°F (200°C) for 20–25 minutes.
Serve warm.

name: Ropa Vieja
blurb: Tender strands of meat simmered with vegetables in a rich, aromatic sauce that's both rustic and deeply comforting.

instructions: Boil flank steak until tender, shred with forks.
Sauté onion, pepper, and garlic in olive oil.
Add tomatoes, cumin, salt, pepper, and beef.
Simmer for 30–40 minutes until flavors meld.
Serve with rice or plantains.

name: Tom Yum Soup
blurb: A hot and sour soup bursting with herbal aroma and a fiery tang, often served with tender seafood or mushrooms.

instructions: Boil lemongrass and lime leaves in broth for 10 minutes.
Add mushrooms and shrimp, cook until shrimp is pink.
Stir in chilies, fish sauce, and lime juice.
Serve hot with cilantro garnish.

name: Bibimbap
blurb: A vibrant bowl layered with assorted vegetables, protein, and a spicy sauce, all mixed together just before eating.

instructions: Arrange warm rice in a bowl.
Top with neatly arranged vegetables and a fried egg.
Drizzle with soy sauce and sesame oil.
Add gochujang to taste.
Mix everything thoroughly before eating.

name: Jollof Rice
blurb: A bold and vibrant one-pot rice dish simmered in a rich tomato base and spiced with peppers and herbs.

instructions: Sauté onion, garlic, and blended pepper in oil.
Add tomato paste and fry until deep red.
Stir in rice and broth, bring to boil.
Cover and simmer on low heat until rice is cooked and fluffy.
Stir occasionally to prevent burning.
